newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa's NUM rejects employer wage offer- paper.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's NUM rejects employer wage offer- paper.

text.p: The National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) on Friday rejected a key element of a precedent-setting Chamber of Mines wage offer for this year, Business Day newspaper reported on Monday.
The paper reported employers saying the offer was designed to deal with a "crisis of major proportions" in the gold mining industry.
The proposal envisaged a three year agreement which would see minimum wages at most affiliated mines increased to 1,000 rand for surface workers and 1,150 rand for underground workers from July 1.
Wages for underground workers would further be increased to 1,450 rand from mid-1999.
This represents an increase this year of up to 33 percent at the lowest-paying mines affected by the proposal.
Underground minimum wages range from 863 rand at mines administered by Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd to 1,129 rand at Anglogold (where the new minimum wage would be 1,231 rand a month).
Other workers would receive nine percent increases in each of the three years.
NUM general secretary Kgalema Motlanthe said at the weekend the union had rejected the "conditionalities" of the offer, and the chamber negotiating team had undertaken to go back to their principles.
But he expressed optimism about the future of the negotiations.
